Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Mechanical Interactions in Tissue Formation and Body Axis Specification

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite their remarkable diversity, all animals begin as a single, fertilized egg. How patterns are established from an initially near uniform system, the egg, is a fundamental question in biology. Mechanical interactions between cells and their environment are thought to play an important role in tissue and axis formation, but this has been difficult to dissect experimentally because of the complexity of developing embryos. The award will investigate the role of mechanical forces in the formation of body form of the Hydra from a solution of separated cells. How the tension at the cell surface and the stiffness of layers of tissue fibers that the cells secrete change how the animal structure develops also will be measured. This award supports fundamental research aimed at studying a simple animal that can regenerate its body after dissociation into individual cells. The core mechanical mechanisms of cell-cell interactions during body plan development are universal during early development. Understanding how these mechanisms work in a simple organism will lead to insight into these mechanisms in more complex beings. This research may reveal general guiding principles for tissue assembly and organ formation and thus has implications for medicine in the context of engineering tissues and organs for transplantation. Understanding how an organism can emerge from an aggregation of cells sparks human imagination. Therefore this project will offer exciting research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. The interdisciplinary nature of the project requires the application of tools from physics, biology, engineering, and computer science, and thus will enable students from diverse backgrounds to make significant contributions.

It is experimentally challenging to dissect the mechanical interactions involved in animal development. A novel system which promises to allow such a dissection is the freshwater polyp Hydra, which self-organizes and regenerates after dissociation into a suspension of single cells. Because of this remarkable ability and its structural simplicity, regenerating Hydra aggregates are fully accessible to quantitative measurements and controlled perturbations while providing an in vivo environment that makes the measurements meaningful. This research will elucidate how tissue formation occurs from a cell suspension and determine the mechanisms that lead to body axis specification. For both processes, the research team will apply a multiscale approach from the molecular to the organismal level and test the importance of mechanical interactions using physical measurements, chemical manipulations, visualization of gene expression using transgenic animals and immunohistochemistry, and fluorescent time-lapse microscopy. This study will provide insight into how macroscopic organism-level patterning emerges from interactions on the cellular level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most animal life begins as a single, fertilized egg. How complex biological patterns emerge from this simple, uniform starting condition is a fundamental question in biology. In addition to well-known biochemical signals, mechanical signals are also thought to play an important role in pattern formation; however, how these two types of signaling mechanisms interact is unclear. To gain new insights into how mechanics may influence organismal patterning, this award funded research aimed at studying Hydra, an anatomically simple freshwater animal with the remarkable ability to regenerate its body after being broken down into a ?soup? of cells, called a cell aggregate. Just like one can assemble bricks into a complex structure and take them apart again, Hydra can be broken down into individual cells and then completely rebuilt from these cellular building blocks. Since mechanical interactions between cells and each other or their environment are universal in biology, understanding how these work in a simple animal like Hydra can help decipher these mechanisms in more complex animals, including humans.

Intellectual Merit. Combining experimental and theoretical work, this research settled a decades-old debate by elucidating the mechanisms that drive tissue formation and organization during regeneration from aggregated cells (Cochet-Escartin et al., Biophysical Journal, 2017). Because the sorting of cells into separate tissues is universally observed in animal development, the insights gained from this work are likely relevant to other organisms which are harder to manipulate. In addition, this research clarified another long-standing question regarding shape changes during later stages of regeneration from cell aggregates. After cell sorting is complete, the regenerating ball of Hydra cells will oscillate in shape by expanding and contracting periodically. Our work (Wang et al., BioRxiv 2019) revealed that the observed shape oscillation pattern is not closely linked to axis specification as previously assumed. Thus, this work disproved a critical assumption that was used to generate mathematical models of Hydra regeneration. This has raised an exciting new research avenue to try to figure out what role these shape oscillations play during regeneration. In addition to the new insights into Hydra regeneration, during the course of this award, new research methods were developed that will greatly benefit the Hydra research community, including an improved method for the maintenance of nerve-free Hydra (Tran et al., JoVE 2017) and the introduction of a new, non-toxic and reversible anesthetic that is easy and safe to work with. This new anesthetic promises to be useful not only in research settings but also for Hydra experiments in classroom settings.

Broader Impacts. Nine undergraduate students and three graduate students from diverse backgrounds actively engaged in this research. Their significant contributions resulted in 4 student co-authored manuscripts. Furthermore, through the launch of a new course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE) quantitative laboratory course, an even larger number of undergraduate students were able to engage in meaningful research experiences, greatly enhancing their learning experience and love for Science. Additionally, this award has supported the launch of a new, personalized mentoring program for women in STEM to provide career support across all levels, from freshman to assistant professor. By using modern research tools and a simple organism, Hydra, this work has allowed us to settle a decade-old debate and rectify wrong assumptions about the role of fundamental mechano-biological interactions for organismal patterning during animal development.
